title: The Brain of Morbius
writers: Robin Bland (a pseudonym for Terrance Dicks, Robert Holmes)
dialogue_triumphs: 'I am still here. I can see nothing, feel nothing. You have locked me into hell for an eternity… Trapped like this, like a sponge beneath the sea. Yet even a sponge has more life than I. Can you understand a thousandth of my agony? I, Morbius, who once led the High Council of the Time Lords, reduced to this – to the condition where I envy a vegetable.'
The Doctor on the elixir: 'The impossible dream of a thousand alchemists, dripping like tea from an urn.'
goofs: Morbius's globe-head falls apart when he tumbles over the cliff edge, and the camera bounces.
Why doesn't Solon just put the brain into the Doctor's head?

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: The protagonist Time Lord, born on Gallifrey within a few billion miles of Karn.

continuity_notes.name: Morbius
continuity_notes.description: Former leader of the High Council of Time Lords, now reduced to a disembodied brain.

continuity_notes.name: The Sisterhood
continuity_notes.description: Guardians of the Sacred Flame or Flame of Life on Karn, equal to Time Lords in mental prowess.

continuity_notes.name: Elixir of Life
continuity_notes.description: A substance produced by the Sacred Flame on Karn, capable of granting eternal life.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time and space travel machine, currently experiencing calibration issues.

technobabble: The TARDIS calibrators are on the blink.
Solon specialises in microsurgical techniques in tissue transplants.
roots: Terrance Dicks's Seven Keys to Doomsday
links: Sarah thinks the Doctor is asking her to crawl through the ventilation system in episode four (as in 'The Ark in Space').

locations.name: Karn
locations.description: A planet in a solar system with five planets, home to the Sisterhood and the Sacred Flame.
locations.current_status: Site of the story's events, far in the future

future_history: Karn's civilization, along with many others, was destroyed by Morbius in his quest for the elixir of life.
untold_adventures: The Doctor's involvement in or knowledge of Morbius's capture and trial
qv: The Location of Gallifrey, 'Terror of the Autons'
additional_notes: The episode features a controversial scene showing faces that might indicate the Doctor had more than three previous bodies, contradicting other stories.
bottom_line: A superb exploration of gothic themes. Philip Madoc's portrayal of Solon is crucial to the story's success, and the pseudonymous epithet 'bland' is not at all deserved.
